org.codemonkey.swiftsocketserver
Class ClientEndpointUDP

java.lang.Object
  org.codemonkey.swiftsocketserver.ClientEndpointUDP
All Implemented Interfaces:
ClientEndpoint
 class ClientEndpointUDP
extends Object
implements ClientEndpoint

Client endpoint that handles UDP traffic and maintains a list of known and new datagram messages.

Since:
1.0
Author:
Benny Bottema
See Also:

CONNECT

public static final String CONNECT
Contains the value that is the command received from a client when making first contact, so that the server knows where to send the UDP messages.

Value: "CONNECT".

ClientEndpointUDP

public ClientEndpointUDP(ServerEndpointUDP serverEndpointUDP,
                         DatagramSocket datagramSocket,
                         DatagramPacket datagramPacket)
Constructor; performs a handshake verification by responding with an acknowledgment command to a handshake connection request.

Parameters:
serverEndpointUDP - The server endpoint from which we can remove clients if necessary.
datagramSocket - The DatagramSocket to send messages to the client with.
datagramPacket - The initial DatagramPacket received from the client that should be a handshake request.

verifyHandshake

private void verifyHandshake(DatagramPacket datagramPacket)
Verifies that the first message to the server is an '"CONNECT"' so we can complete the handshake by sending an '"ACK" '

Parameters:
datagramPacket - The request message from the client that must contain the connect handshake value.

handleDatagramPacket

public void handleDatagramPacket(DatagramPacket datagramPacket)
Adds a datagram packet to the queue to be processed, which is done by calling readLine(). This is so that it mimics how TCP messages are read, molded into a uniform abstraction (ClientEndpoint).

The difference between TCP and UDP is that UDP messages are pushed, by TCP messages can be pulled by the system. And so we need to cache (or 'queue') the UDP messages until they are pulled by the server the same way TCP messages are being pulled.

Parameters:
datagramPacket - The DatagramPacket to add to the queue waiting for readLine() calls the same way a TCP messages are retrieved by the server.

readLine

public String readLine()
                throws IOException
Returns a String line from the next DatagramPacket in the queue. This is done by using a BufferedReader to read DatagramPacket.getData(). If there are no datagram packets to convert to a string line, this method blocks until a datagram packet is received or the socket has been closed.

Specified by:
readLine in interface ClientEndpoint
Returns:
A complete datagram packet value read using BufferedReader.readLine() so that it detects the newline and zero/NULL character.
Throws:
IOException - Thrown by BufferedReader.readLine().

read

public void read()
Does nothing, since the entire message is conveyed by a DatagramPacket and we don't need the extra read for get out the NULL character (which was needed in case of Flash clients on TCP sockets).

Specified by:
read in interface ClientEndpoint
